description: Probably from Scots curfuffle, equivalent to ker- +‎ fuffle, or related to Irish cior thual (“char athwart: confusion, disorder”). Similar to modern Welsh cythrwfl (“uproar, trouble, agitation”)

entries.meaning: (chiefly Commonwealth, informal) A disorderly outburst, disturbance, commotion, or tumult. [from 19th c.]
examples: Synonyms: brouhaha, donnybrook, fracas, hubbub, hullabaloo, mess, racket

verbs.description: kerfuffle (third-person singular simple present kerfuffles, present participle kerfuffling, simple past and past participle kerfuffled)

entries.meaning: (chiefly Britain, informal) To make a disorderly outburst or commotion.
